passages.text: Reiterate Rating: BUY | PO: 1,200 GBP | Price: 966.40 GBP

Prudential is a double- digit growth company. It delivered another solid semester of new business growth and added a capital return angle. Prudential is our sector top pick, a member of our department's Europe 1 and Q3 best ideas lists. Our earnings forecasts are little changed overall but we increase our price objective by \(4\%\) to 12 (ADR moves to USD32.97 with FX) as we roll forward our valuation and increase our capital return forecasts. Reiterate Buy rating.

We forecast \(15\%\) CAGR in Pru's dividend per share 2024- 27E. This is higher than the new target for \(>10\%\) pa growth in 2025- 27 but lower than our forecast for new OFSG 2024- 27E (26% CAGR). Pru reaffirmed that its dividend should grow broadly in- line with net OFSG over the medium term but it grew faster than this over 2023/24 and we think it may be a little slower in 2025- 27. \(15\%\) DPS CAGR is still an appealing growth rate. We think the \(>10\%\) pa DPS growth target is designed to be a long- term target, which should not have to be revised even when net OFSG growth slows longer- term.

Pru has committed to a \(\) 500m\(buyback in 2026, on top of the\) \ \(1bn\) one- off buyback we have included in our model, and a further \(\) 600m\(buyback in 2027. Overall, we think Pru will still have a spare\) \ \(600m\) of totally free cash generation in 2027E and will have over \(\) 1.3bn\(of excess capital at all times 2025 - 27E. Pru has scope for even more capital return; cash is not a binding constraint.

New business margins beat our expectations in H1 and should seasonally improve further in H2. This should power double- digit growth in new business profits, IFRS operating profits, book value per share and dividends 2024- 27E. This deserves a premium multiple, in our view. With Pru shares trading on just 9.5x 2027E earnings and now offering a \(6.9\%\) all- in capital return yield in 2026E, we see further re- rating ahead.

l><ecel><fcel><fcel><fcel><ecel><fcel><fcel><fcel><ecel><fcel><fcel><fcel><ecel><fcel><fcel><fcel><ecel><fcel><fcel><fcel><ecel><fcel><fcel><fcel><ecel><fcel><fcel><fcel><ecel><fcel><fcel><fcel><ecel><fcel><fcel><fcel><ecel><fcel><fcel><fcel><ecel><fcel><fcel><fcel><ecel><fcel><fcel><fcel><ecel><fcel><fcel><fcel><ecel><fcel><fcel><fcel><ecel><fcel><fcel><fcel><ecel><fcel><fcel><fcel><ecel><fcel><fcel><fcel><ecel><fcel><fcel><fcel><ecel><fcel><fcel><fcel><ecel><fcel><fcel><fcel><ecel><fcel><fcel><fcel><ecel><fcel><fcel><fcel><ecel><fcel><fcel><fcel><ecel><fcel><fcel><fcel><ecel><fcel><fcel><fcel><ecel><fcel><fcel><fcel><ecel><fcel><fcel><fcel><ecel><fcel><fcel><fcel><ecel><fcel><fcel><fcel><ecel><fcel><fcel><fcel><ecel><fcel><fcel><fcel><ecel><fcel><fcel><fcel><ecel><fcel><fcel><fcel><ecel><fcel><fcel><fcel><ecel><fcel><fcel><fcel><ecel><fcel><fcel><fcel><ecel><fcel><fcel><fcel><ecel><fcel><fcel><fcel><ecel><fcel><fcel><fcel><ecel><fcel><fcel><fcel><ecel><fcel><fcel><fcel><ecel><fcel><fcel><fcel><ecel><fcel><fcel><fcel><ecel><fcel><fcel><fcel><ecel><fcel><fcel><fcel><ecel><fcel><fcel><fcel><ecel><fcel><fcel><fcel><ecel><fcel><fcel><fcel><ecel><fcel><fcel><fcel><ecel><fcel><fcel><fcel><ecel><fcel><fcel><fcel><ecel><fcel><fcel><fcel><ecel><fcel><fcel><fcel><ecel><fcel><fcel><fcel><ecel><fcel><fcel><fcel><ecel><fcel><fcel><fcel><ecel><fcel><fcel><fcel><ecel><fcel><fcel><fcel><ecel><fcel><fcel><fcel><ecel><fcel><fcel><fcel><ecel><fcel><fcel><fcel><ecel><fcel><fcel><fcel><ecel><fcel><fcel><fcel><ecel><fcel><fcel><fcel><ecel><fcel><fcel><fcel><ecel><fcel><fcel><fcel><ecel><fcel><fcel><fcel><ecel><fcel><fcel><fcel><ecel><fcel><fcel><fcel><ecel><fcel><fcel><fcel><ecel><fcel><fcel><fcel><ecel><fcel><fcel><fcel><ecel><fcel><fcel><fcel><ecel><fcel><fcel><fcel><ecel><fcel><fcel><fcel><ecel><fcel><fcel><fcel><ecel><fcel><fcel><fcel><ecel><fcel><fcel><fcel><ecel><fcel><fcel><fcel><ecel><fcel><fcel><fcel><ecel><fcel><fcel><fcel><ecel><fcel><fcel><fcel><ecel><fcel><fcel><fcel><ecel><fcel><fcel><fcel><ecel><fcel><fcel><fcel><ecel><fcel><fcel><fcel><ecel><fcel><fcel><fcel><ecel><fcel><fcel><fcel><ecel><fcel><fcel><fcel><ecel><fcel><fcel><fcel><ecel><fcel><fcel><fcel><ecel><fcel><fcel><fcel><ecel><fcel><fcel><fcel><ecel><fcel><fcel><fcel><ecel><fcel><fcel><fcel><ecel><fcel><fcel><fcel><ecel><fcel><fcel><fcel><ecel><fcel><fcel><fcel><ecel><fcel><fcel><fcel><ecel><fcel><fcel><fcel><ecel><fcel><fcel><fcel><ecel><fcel><fcel><fcel><ecel><fcel><fcel><fcel><ecel><fcel><fcel><f

1. Don't doubt the dividends: Pru's dividend could grow well above its \(>10\%\) target, which is an 'enduring framework' to last more than three years. Prudential announced a capital management update with its H1 results, including both dividend and buyback messaging. We consider buybacks in point 2, with dividends considered here.

Pru announced its dividends for 2025- 27 will grow \(>10\%\) per annum. This reaffirms Pru's double-digit growth credentials, but existing (and reiterated) guidance for growing with net OFSG means more.

Pru had previously stated that it planned to grow its dividend over the medium term with net operating free surplus generation (net OFSG). The company reiterated this guidance today, which suggests materially higher growth than \(10\%\) is feasible. We forecast net operating free surplus generation growing \(26\%\) CAGR 2024- 27E.
Exhibit 1: Prudential operating free surplus generation (Sm) 2024-27E We think Pru can reach its target of \(\) 4.4bn\(gross OFSG in 2027E, with net OFSG growing\)25\% \(CAGR to\) \ \(3.4bn\)

20242025E2026E2027EGross OFSG Insurance2,3912,8623,5174,044Asset management OFSG275295324357Gross OFSG2,6663,1573,8414,401Investment in new business-682-793-867-941Segment OFSG1,9842,3652,9743,460Other costs-265-350-200-50Net OFSG1,7192,0152,7743,410
Source: BofA Global Research estimates, Company reports

This includes gross operating free surplus generation growing at \(18\%\) CAGR to \(\) 4,412\(m in 2027E, essentially in - line with Pru's target for\) \ \(4.4bn\) in 2027E. New business is becoming more efficient over time and other costs (including restructuring costs) should reduce over time as Pru's initiatives complete.
Exhibit 2: Dividends are set to grow \(15\%\) CAGR as OFSG accelerates Net OFSG per share and dividend per share growth (\%) and Dividend per share (USDc), 2022-2030E
Source: Company reports, BofA Global Research estimates

Pru's dividend grew faster than net OFSG growth in recent years, as the company began its \(1bn investment programme and suffered from adverse experience variances. However, the company looked through this temporary blip when growing its dividend. Similarly, we think Pru will look through the brief spike in net OFSG growth as the investment spend declines and drag from variances reduces. We forecast \(15\%\) DPS CAGR 2024- 27E.
We forecast \(15\%\) CAGR in dividend per share 2024- 27E.
On this basis, it suggests Pru's target for over \(10\%\) pa dividend per share growth looks low. We think this policy is designed to stand the test of time, and should be valid well- beyond 2027.
We think Pru's policy of DPS growth over \(10\%\) pa is one for the next decade and beyond, not just three years.

We see DPS growth above \(10\%\) even in the outer years for Prudential. Even in the outer years, Pru's dividend payout is only around a \(31\%\) payout of cash remittance (or only a \(22 - 23\%\) payout of net OFSG).
Exhibit 3: Pru's dividend payout ratio remains low Dividend payout of remitted cash and net OFSG, 2024-2030E
Source: BofA Global Research estimates, Company reports
BofA GLOBAL RESEARCH

Overall, we think Pru's dividend yield will improve, doubling in 5 year from \(2.0\%\) for 2025E to \(4.0\%\) in 2030 but is not the main reason for investors to own the stock. Growth is the main reason we think investors should own Pru. Top line growth is strong and bottom- line growth will likely be further boosted by Pru's new buyback policy.
Pru has introduced annual buybacks into its capital return plans for the first time.

The company has indicated it will buy back \(\) 500m\(of stock in 2025 and a further\) \ \(600m\) in 2026. This is in addition to any proceeds from its planned IPO of its Indian asset management operations (see report).
This increases Prudential's all- in capital return yield to \(6.8\%\) in 2026E and \(4.6\%\) in 2027E (having returned \(6.0\%\) for 2025E including the remaining buyback).
Exhibit 4: Prudential capital returns 2025-30E We forecast growing dividends and annual buybacks
Source: Company reports, BofA Global Research estimates
BofA GLOBAL RESEARCH

These capital returns are appealing but are far from a stretch for Pru. We think Pru has scope to go further. The company has ample free cash at holding company. We forecast holding company cash growing strongly even after \(15\%\) DPS CAGR and \(\) 2.1\(bn of buybacks over 2026/27E.

Exhibit 5: Prudential holding company cash (\$m) Pru's HoldCo cash will continue to grow even after allowing for annual buybacks. This provides flexibility for bolt-ons, bigger buybacks or faster dividend growth.
Source: Company reports, BofA Global Research estimates

Our remittance forecasts are based on \(70\%\) of segment OFSG being remitted to holding company, in- line with Prudential's guidance. This implies over \(\) 2.4bn\(of remittance in 2027E. After central costs of around\) \ \(0.5bn\) and dividends of almost \(\) 750m\(this leaves around\) \ \(1.2bn\) of totally free cash.
This suggests Pru's \(\) 600m\(buyback is around half of its totally free cash flow in 2027E. Similarly, the 2026E organic buyback would be around half of our totally free cash

forecasts if there is no further capital injection into Mainland China (we forecast a \(\) 200m\(injection but excluding this injection the free cash would be around\) \ \(900m\) , so a \(\) 500m\(organic buyback is close to half of this).
Looking another way, Prudential has indicated it will consider returning capital above a \(200\%\) free surplus ratio. We think Pru will remain above \(218\%\) even after all planned capital returns.
Exhibit 6: Prudential free surplus ratio (\%) and excess capital above \(200\%\) (\$bn), 2024-2030E Pru will have over \$1bn of excess capital even after dividend growth and buybacks
Source: BofA Global Research estimates, Company reports
We think Prudential has ample scope for further capital return, even after the \(\) 2.1bn\(of buybacks we forecast over\) 2026 - 27E.

We comment briefly on slide 6 from Prudential's interim results slide pack. This slide indicated that \(2026's\) total capital returns in USD terms would be slightly higher than \(2025's\) and that \(2027\) would be higher again than \(2026\) .

It is worth also briefly considering Pru's total payout ratio. We think Pru will pay out around \(70 - 75\%\) of free cashflow over \(2026 / 27E\) in terms of organic capital returns. By organic capital returns we mean dividends and buybacks funded from cashflow (i.e. excluding any one- off returns of excess capital).
We consider Prudential's payout ratio for organic capital returns (dividend plus buybacks funded out of cashflow) compared to net OFSG, cash remittance to HoldCo and free cash after holding costs
Source: BofA Global Research estimates
BofA GLOBAL RESEARCH

Prudential posted a strong update on new business profits, with a \(12\%\) growth YoY to \(\) 1,260\(m (after allocation of central costs). This is another quarter of double - digit growth, building confidence in its commitment of double - digit growth in NBP in 2025 and\) 15 - 22\% \(CAGR 2022 - 27.\)

H1 new business profits beat expectations, driven by a higher margin business on top of \(5\%\) volume growth on an APE (annual premium equivalent) basis. H1's new business margin of \(38.3\%\) (as \(0\%\) of APE) was up \(2\%\) pts YoY, driven by an improvement in business mix (products and geographies), with contribution from positive repricing actions.
Prudential reiterated its target of 2022- 2027E new business profit CAGR target of \(15 - 20\%\) , which translates to a 2024- 2027E CAGR of \(11 - 19\%\) on a TEV basis.

While H1's margin of \(38\%\) is attractive, and higher than we had expected, this should improve further in the coming quarters. This is mainly driven by increasing share of bancassurance sales, as well as growing health and protection sales in H2 compared to H1. This suggests a higher margin product mix in H2 than H1.
Seasonality impact in margins suggest that Pru will write even higher margin new business in 3Q and 4Q.
Source: Company reports, BofA Global Research estimates
BofA GLOBAL RESEARCH

Pru has indicated margins should sequentially increase through Q1- Q4 each year. We saw this as Q2 margins of \(42.4\%\) were a step up from Q1's \(36.3\%\) . We forecast increasing margins in 3Q and 4Q of \(43.6\%\) and \(45.7\%\) respectively, leading to a FY25 NB margin of \(42.0\%\) (based on NBP pre- allocation of central costs), up \(1.3\%\) pts YoY.

We forecast \(10\%\) CAGR in new business profits from 2024- 2027E, reaching \(3.4bn\) in 2027E. This is supported by a 2024- 2027E APE CAGR of \(10\%\) , and stable attractive high new business margins around \(41 - 42\%\)

Our forecasts are slightly lower than Pru's target for new business profit growth, which suggests some upside risk to our forecasts (the range is \(3 - 28\%\) above our 2027E forecast). We remain cautious of margin pressure in Mainland China and lower APE growth in some regions. An evolving product mix towards less- capital intensive, but also low margin participating products could put some pressure on new business profits.

Pru has also guided for a double- digit growth of its IFRS operating profits per share. This will mainly come from growth in its contractual service margin (CSM). Pru's new business growth was muted for several years due to Covid restrictions, depressing CSM growth, but this has reaccelerated and is starting to feed through to faster operating profit growth.

Pru targets \(>10\%\) growth in IFRS adjusted operating profit after tax (per share) in 2025E. We forecast an \(8\%\) increase in adjusted operating profits, leading to a \(12\%\) growth in operating EPS. Looking longer- term, we see \(15\%\) operating EPS CAGR 2024- 27E in USD terms, or \(13\%\) CAGR in GBP terms.
Adjusted operating profit after tax (per share) will grow faster than the underlying operating profit as the share count continues to decline amid Pru's ongoing buybacks.

As discussed above, with an uptick in new business after COVID recovery, we expect accelerated CSM growth of \(10\%\) in 2025, and c. \(9\%\) pa in 2026- 2027. This should contribute to the higher operating profit growth through higher CSM release to the P&L.

This ultimately feeds through the net profit to the shareholders' equity per share, growing \(13\%\) CAGR 2024- 27E (in USD terms) and c. \(10\%\) CAGR in total comprehensive equity per share 2024- 2027E.
Exhibit 9: Prudential's growth metrics 2023-2027E
Source: Company reports, BofA Global Research estimates

Pru is a structurally growing business. New business profits, IFRS operating profits, CSM, and Shareholders' equity are all growing above \(10\%\) CAGR 2024- 27E on a per share basis. We think this deserves a premium rating

Results recap- A solid H1 results update came slightly ahead of expectations on all key metrics.- Pru is demonstrating double- digit growth on all key metrics, which should sustain for the foreseeable future.- This was accompanied by a capital management update which exceeded our expectations.- Pru has also made a commitment on capital return to shareholders through dividends and annual buybacks.- Pru is our sector top pick, a Europe 1 list stock, and on our department's Q3 best ideas list - Buy.
- New business profits rose 12% YoY to \(\) 1,260m\(after allocation of central costs), which was 2% ahead of our forecast and 1% ahead of consensus.
- This was supported by strong margins, as new business volumes on an APE basis were up 5% YoY in-line with consensus, while margins expanded to 38% (from 36%) on a positive mix.
- Pru is still on track to grow new business profits at a double-digit pace in 2025 and beyond.
- Its reiterated new business targets imply 11-19% new business profit CAGR 2024-27E.
- IFRS op profits rose 6% YoY to \(\) 1,644m\(, which was 4% ahead of BoFAe and 1% ahead of consensus.
- Earnings per share rose 12% YoY and guidance for double-digit growth in 2025 reiterated.
- Operating free surplus generation (Pru's metric for cash) grew 14% YoY to \(\) 1,560m\(and again double-digit growth guidance was reiterated for 2025.
- The CSM (stock of future profits) was also a 3% beat, annualising at 8% underlying growth.
- An H1 interim dividend of 7.71p per share was formulaic and in-line, up 13% YoY.
- More important was Pru's capital management update. The company has committed to return the majority of its annual flow of capital generation, including annual capital returns (read buybacks).
- The company should grow its dividend \(>10\%\) CAGR 2024-27E and broadly in-line with net OFSG.
- We forecast 15% DPS CAGR 2024-27E and see more upside than downside risk to this forecast as we forecast 22% net OFSG CAGR.
- Pru will also conduct a \(\) 500m\(buyback in 2026 in addition to any one - off capital returns.
- This will be followed by a \(\) 600m\(buyback in 2027. This totals\)\\(600m\) more buybacks than we forecast ( \(\) 500m\(extra in 2026 &\)\\(100m\) in 2027).
- Pru will have flexibility for more and plans to return capital over 200% free surplus ratio (suggests \(>\) 1bn flex).
- TEV of \(\) 34.2bn\(958p per share) excluding goodwill was in - line and up 2% YTD.
- RoEV improved 2%pts YoY to 15% but capital returns and adverse FX tempered growth in the headline TEV.
- Adverse experience variances have also begun to reduce (only -\)28m drag in 1H25 vs \(\) 80m\(in 1H24 and set to be +ve in'27), which supports EV & OFSG growth.
Prudential delivered a solid H1 update with small beats on most key lines.

We refresh our forecasts
Source: Company reports, BofA Global Research estimates
We increase our new business profit forecasts slightly on higher margins, despite trimming our volume forecasts slightly.
We increase our operating EPS forecasts by about 1%.
Our dividend forecasts are unchanged but we add an extra $500m to our 2026E buyback and $100m to our 2027E buyback assumptions (now $1.5bn and $600m respectively).
We increase our price objective to £12 (ADR moves with FX to USD32.97). At our PO, the stock would trade on 13x 2026E earnings.
Exhibit 12: Prudential Plc IFRS based Sum Parts (USm)
The table below sets out the detail of our valuation of Prudential

Our 1,200p price objective (USD32.97 per ADR) is based on our sum- of- the- parts valuation, rolled forward 12 months. In addition to a multiple of allocated capital per division, we also back out an implied earnings multiple from our fair value. We assume \(13.5\%\) discount rate and \(7\%\) growth rate for Asia life, \(12\%\) discount rate and \(6\%\) growth for Eastspring and market value for the Indian JV. Our risk discount rates have been adjusted higher to reflect both higher interest rates and greater macro uncertainty.
Overall, our PO represents a multiple of \(13\times 2026E\) IFRS EPS. This is above the European sector average fair multiple reflecting superior long term growth prospects for Asia.
Downside risks to our PO are 1) emerging market currency weakness, 2) equity market weakness, 3) political and/or economic upheaval in some of Prudential's emerging market operations.
Upside risks to our PO are 1) better- than- expected macro conditions, 2) higher equity markets, 3) positive surprises on capital management.

iQmethod the set of BofA Global Research standard measures that serve to maintain global consistency under three broad headings: Business Performance, Quality of Earnings, and validations. The key features of iQmethod are: A consistently structured, detailed, and transparent methodology. Guidelines to maximize the effectiveness of the comparative valuation process, and to identify some common pitfalls. iQatobase is our real-time global research database that is sourced directly from our equity analysts' earnings models and includes forecasted as well as historical data for income statements, balance sheets, and cash flow statements for companies covered by BofA Global Research. iQprofile, iQmethod are services marks of Bank of America Corporation. iQatobase is a registered service mark of Bank of America Corporation.

FUNDAMENTAL EQUITY OPINION KEY: Opinions include a Volatility Risk Rating, an Investment Rating and an Income Rating. VOLATILITY RISK RATINGS, indicators of potential price fluctuation, are: A - Low, B - Medium and C - High. INVESTMENT RATINGS reflect the analyst's assessment of both a stock's absolute total return potential as well as its attractiveness for investment relative to other stocks within its Coverage Cluster (defined below). Our investment ratings are: 1 - Buy stocks are expected to have a total return of at least \(10\%\) and are the most attractive stocks in the coverage cluster; 2 - Neutral stocks are expected to remain flat or increase in value and are less attractive than Buy rated stocks and 3 - Underperform stocks are the least attractive stocks in a coverage cluster. An investment rating of 6 (No Rating) indicates that a stock is no longer trading on the basis of fundamentals. Analysts assign investment ratings considering, among other things, the 0- 12 month total return expectation for a stock and the firm's guidelines for ratings dispersions (shown in the table below). The current price objective for a stock should be referenced to better understand the total return expectation at any given time. The price objective reflects the analyst's view of the potential price appreciation (depreciation).
Investment ratingTotal return expectation (within 12-month period of date of initial rating)Ratings dispersion guidelines for coverage clusterR2Buy≥ 10%≤ 70%Neutral≥ 0%≤ 30%UnderperformN/A≥ 20%
R2Ratings dispersions may vary from time to time where BofA Global Research believes it better reflects the investment prospects of stocks in a Coverage Cluster.

INCOME RATINGS, indicators of potential cash dividends, are: 7 - same/higher (dividend considered to be secure), 8 - same/lower (dividend not considered to be secure) and 9 - pays no cash dividend. Coverage Cluster is comprised of stocks covered by a single analyst or two or more analysts sharing a common industry, sector, region or other classification(s). A stock's coverage cluster is included in the most recent BofA Global Research report referencing the stock.
Price Charts for the securities referenced in this research report are available on the Price Charts website, or call 1- 800- MERRILL to have them mailed.

uyback assumptions (now $1.5bn and $600m respectively). We increase our price objective to £12 (ADR moves with FX to USD32.97). At our PO, the stock would trade on 13x 2026E earnings. # Financ
